Sulpicius also proposed a change in the method of judicial procedure: we hear now for the first time of iudices editicii to try cases of bribery‚ bis proposal being that there should be 125 jurors nominated (editi) by the accuser out of the decun'ae of equites and aerarii tribuni, of which the defendant might challenge (reicere) 75, leaving 50, so that there should be a jury of 75 in all, including 25 senators who were to be appointed in some other way107. These proposals, how- ever, of Sulpicius were not carried 3 but the bill proposed by Cicero (lex Tullia de ambitu), occasioned by the electoral corruption of the preceding year, was more successful. It was supplementary to the lex Acilia Calpurm'alll, defining the proofs of guilt more closely and adding to penalties fixed by it in the case of senatorial candidates ten years exile. lt also forbade certain practices tending to influence the electors un- duly even when money was not offered, such as the presence of crowds of hired attendants (deductores and sectatores). It seems also to bave imposed penalties on the dz'aisores109. It also forbade ‘treating,’ as no person was allowed to exhibit gladiatorial shows or give public payments within two years before he was a candidate, except under the peculiar circum- stances of its being required by a testamentary disposition¹⁰².
